docs.title: Feature Tracker
docs.text: The feature tracker application will serve as a centralized hub for product development teams and users to monitor the implementation status of features across multiple products, track their release cycles, and identify areas for improvement. Additionally, user feedback will be collected and analyzed to provide actionable insights on which features are most well-received by users.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
You need to install the following software:

  • JDK 21 or later
  • Docker (installation instructions)
  • IntelliJ IDEA
  • Taskfile

docs.title: Application Architecture
docs.text:
The feature tracker application is being developed following Microservices Architecture. This application has the following services:

  • feature-service: Manages products, features, releases. See more
  • user-service: Manages users by interacting with Keycloak. See more
  • notification-service: Handles events published by other services and sends notification emails. See more
  • config-server: Central Config server to store all the microservices configuration. See more
  • api-gateway: API Gateway to store all the microservices. See more
  • feature-tracker-angular: Frontend SPA for feature-tracker application. See more

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text:
The application components are published as Docker images on DockerHub. The Keycloak Identity Management System is used as an OAuth 2.0 server to secure the application.

IMPORTANT:

Frontend application uses the front-channel to login with Keycloak. Backend microservices use the back-channel to validate auth tokens.

To use the same host name for both scenarios, add the host name keycloak to /etc/hosts file pointing to 127.0.0.1.

127.0.0.1 keycloak

Task is a task runner that we can use to run any arbitrary commands in an easier way.

Install Task CLI.

$ brew install go-task
(or)
$ go install github.com/go-task/task/v3/cmd/task@latest

#verify task version
$ task --version
Task version: 3.35.1

Now, you can run the application locally using docker-compose as follows:

$ git clone https://github.com/feature-tracker/docker-infra.git
$ cd docker-infra
$ task start

You can access the Feature Tracker application at http://localhost:4200

docs.title: Local Development
docs.text:
1.Clone the repositories

$ git clone https://github.com/feature-tracker/docker-infra.git
$ git clone https://github.com/feature-tracker/api-gateway.git
$ git clone https://github.com/feature-tracker/config-server.git
$ git clone https://github.com/feature-tracker/feature-service.git
$ git clone https://github.com/feature-tracker/notification-service.git
$ git clone https://github.com/feature-tracker/user-service.git
$ git clone https://github.com/feature-tracker/feature-tracker-angular.git

Alternatively, you can use IntelliJ IDEA Workspace support to clone all the repositories easily.

First, install Multi-Project Workspace Plugin if you haven't already installed.

From IntelliJ IDEA, clone the ft-workspace repository (https://github.com/feature-tracker/ft-workspace) which will automatically clone all the required Git repositories.

2. Build Docker images of all the components

$ cd docker-infra
$ task build

3.Start the entire application

You can start all the components of the system and their dependent services(Keycloak, databases, message brokers, etc.) using Docker Compose by running the following command:

$ task devstart

Once all the services have been started, you should be able to invoke API endpoints via API Gateway.

Examples:

  • curl http://localhost:8989/features/api/products

You can access the Feature Tracker application at http://localhost:4200

4.Debugging/Running Microservices from IDE

You may want to start the infra components as Docker containers and run specific microservice from IDE.

In that case, start all the infra components(Keycloak, databases, message brokers, etc.) as follows:

$ cd docker-infra
$ task start_infra

Now, you can run the individual microservices from the IDE.
